subject: South Korea September 1st-10th exports rose 7.2% Y/Y and imports rose 3.3% Y/Y
Elders (ELD AT) Chairman Carroll is to step down and Ian Wilton has been elected as his replacement
Tabcorp (TAH AT) was informed that investigation regarding Cambodia has been closed and officials do not intend to take any action

PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Australian Treasurer Frydenberg will announce new powers for ASIC, Japan conducts Cabinet reshuffle, Sources suggested BoJ policymakers may be open to additional easing
content:
AUSTRALIA

Caltex (CTX AT) - Co. is to sell about AUD 120mln of metropolitan service station locations. (Newswires)

Evolution Mining (EVN AT) - Co. exercises option to acquire certain Yuinmery tenements for 1.25% smelter royalty. (Newswires)

Strike Energy (STX AT) - Co. announced significant upgrade of Kingia gas discovery. (Newswires)

Woodside Petroleum (WPL AT) - Co. is seeking to lower stake in Scarborough gas field and Kitimat LNG project in Canada for capital and risk management reasons. (Newswires)

Financials - Treasurer Frydenberg will announce new powers for ASIC as the regulator appeals a controversial judgment which demolished the regulator's allegations of irresponsible lending at Westpac (WBC AT). (AFR)

 

JAPAN

AGC (5201 JT) - Co. is planning to exit South Korea amid ongoing dispute. (Newswires)

Asahi Group Holdings (2502 TT) - Co. is planning to reorganize premium beer business in Europe. (Nikkei)

Japan Post Holdings (7181 JT) - Japanese regulator is expected to begin probe involving the Co. today. (Newswires)

Kagome (2811 JT) - Co. is planning to raise vegetable juice shipments to Asia by 8x. (Nikkei)

Recruit Holdings (6098 JT) - Co. priced share offering at JPY 3079/Shr vs. last close JPY 3175/Shr. (Newswires)

Cabinet Reshuffle - Japanese PM Abe is said to select Yasutoshi Nishimura as Economy Minister in cabinet rejig. (Newswires)

Other News - BoJ policymakers are said to be growing less confident in global growth and may be open to additional easing measures according to sources, while it was suggested the decision on whether to ease will be a close call and that a conclusion may not come until last minute. Furthermore, it was noted that taking rates further into negative territory is among options but other options are not off the table and the sources added if rates go deeper into negative territory, BoJ may need to accompany it with mitigating measures and that deeper negative rates, cutting 10yr JGB target, ramping up purchases of risky assets and printing money are among the options. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

GS Engineering & Construction (006360 KS) - Co. wins KRW 276bln order in Thailand. (Yonhap)

Mirae Asset Global Investments (037620 KS) - Co. will acquire Anbang’s US hotel portfolio for USD 5.8bln. (Newswires)

Samsung Biologics (207940 KS) - Co. Bioepis unit entered Brazilian biopharmaceutical market with its BRENZYS rheumatoid and arthritis treatment. (Newswires)

SK Corp (003600 KS) - SK Siltron will acquire DuPont’s wafer business for USD 450mln. (Yonhap)

subject: ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include Japanese BSI Large Manufacturing and Australian Westpac Consumer Confidence
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China Premier Li said US and China should find a solution to the trade dispute and hopes that talks make progress. (Newswires)

China is ready to sweeten deal by buying American goods in countdown to trade war talks according to a source, although reports added even a simple purchase agreement is no certainty and that purchasing of US goods would be in exchange for a delay on tariffs and easing of restrictions on Huawei. Furthermore, China could offer more market access and better IP protection as well as cutting industrial capacity, but would be reluctant to compromise on subsidies, industrial policies and reform of SOEs. (SCMP)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said it is a grave concern for US President Trump's administration that the Chinese did not live up to its commitments to purchase US Agricultural goods and that this matter will be addressed in upcoming talks. (NY Times)

US Commerce Department's preliminary findings showed that imports of ceramic tiles from China have been subsidized unfairly and therefore have put preliminary duties of 103.77-222.24% on Chinese ceramic tile imports. (Newswires)

BoJ decision on when and whether to ease will be a close call with policymakers growing less confident in global growth, while taking rates further into negative territory is among options but other options are not off the table, according to sources. Furthermore, it was suggested the decision on whether to ease will be a close call and that a conclusion may not come until last minute, while the sources added if rates go deeper into negative territory, BoJ may need to accompany that with mitigating measures and that deepening negative rates, cutting 10yr JGB target, ramping up purchases of risky assets and printing money are among the options. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

BoE Governor Carney said the BoE does not see large imbalances in the economy that would normally precipitate a slowdown and that the BoE has the tools to deal with an economic slowdown. BoE Governor Carney also does not see negative interest rates as a tool in the UK and reiterated the BoE could release countercyclical capital buffers for banks in the event of a downturn. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson spokesman said we are not seeking a Northern Ireland only backstop and made it clear that the PM wants a deal. In related news, DUP leader Foster said an all-Ireland backstop idea has been dismissed by UK PM Johnson and a senior ERG source said if UK PM Johnson goes for an all-Ireland backstop that 'throws the DUP under the bus' and the deal would not get through the Commons. (Newswires/ITV/Twitter)

Incoming European Commission Chief Von Der Leyen said no-deal Brexit preparations are done and that she wants Barnier to remain as the EU's Chief Brexit Negotiator. (Newswires)

Sources reportedly said that the ECB could delay the launch of any QE and tie it to data when it is launched. Furthermore, the report suggested strong disagreement over how much stimulus was needed and that policymakers could lean towards tying it to further economic downside. (Newswires)

Italy is reportedly planning to raise its 2020 deficit goal to circa 2.3% of GDP vs. Prev. target 2.1%. (Newswires)

  • UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Jul) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.9% (Prev. 3.9%). (Newswires)
  • UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Jul) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.9%)
  • UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M (Jul) 4.0% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.7%, Rev. 3.8%)

 

FX

Canada PM Trudeau is expected to call for elections on Wednesday with 21st October the date for the election. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

API Crude Inventories -7.2mln vs. Exp. -2.7mln (Prev. +0.4mln). (Newswires)

US EIA cut forecasts for 2019 world oil demand growth by 100K BPD to a 900k BPD Y/Y increase and cut 2020 world oil demand growth by 30k to a 1.4mln BPD y/y increase, while it sees 2019 US crude output to rise 1.25mln BPD to 12.24mln BPD and sees 2020 US crude output to rise 990k BPD to 13.23mln BPD. (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary-General Barkindo said there are no alternative plans for OPEC+ agreement and that it is committed to taking the necessary decisions to ensure the stability and balance of the global oil market. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Israel PM Netanyahu said he intends to annex Jordan Valley in the West Bank. (Newswires)

UK said it is clear that Iran breached assurances it gave regarding the Grace1/Adrian Darya1 tanker and the oil has been transferred to Syria, while the UK will raise the issue at the United Nations later this month and has summoned the Iran ambassador regarding oil transfers from the tanker to Syria. (Newswires/Al Jazeera)

 

US

US President Trump said he has sacked security advisor John Bolton and that he disagreed strongly with some of Bolton's suggestions. (Newswires)

Apple (APPL) conducted its Launch Event in which it announced streaming, new models for the iWatch, iPhone, iPad and a new health app. Apple's arcade gaming service will be available on 19th September priced at USD 4.99/month and will launch exclusive games not available on any other platforms, while its new iPhone 11 entry level model will be priced at USD 699, PRO model starts at USD 999 and PRO MAX at USD 1099. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple’s (AAPL) new event saw the announcement of a streaming service priced at USD 4.99/mth which weighed on Netflix (NFLX), Disney (DIS) and Roku (ROKU), and a new health app put pressure on Fitbit (FIT). iPhone entry level prices were slightly cheaper than its XR equivalents, with the iPhone 11 to start from USD 699, and the PRO model at USD 999, and the PRO MAX at USD 1099; a new iWatch and iPad were also announced. Ford (F) was hit after is unsecured debt was downgraded to junk at Moody's, however, desks had mixed views, with BofAML suggesting it may be a sign of more to come, whereas Credit Suisse believes it did little to affect Ford’s ongoing business. Boeing’s (BA) gross orders for August stood at 185, however, net orders were -15 due to cancellations, also likely impacted by different airlines pushing back their expected return of the 737 MAX. JPMorgan’s (JPM) CEO Dimon expects Q3 trading revenues to rise 10% Y/Y in Q3, but caveated it with ‘Q318 was not great’. Wendy’s (WEN) announced it is to initiate a breakfast menu at 300 restaurants next year and will hire 20,000 new employees to support the move. The fast food restaurant then cut the top end of its FY19 Adj. EPS growth view to 3.5-6.5% from 3.5-7%. In M&A, Renault (RNO FP) CEO stated it is no longer in discussion with Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) and that the main priority is having Nissan (NSANY) back on schedule. Exxon (XOM) was higher after sources said it was in advanced talks with Repsol (REP SM) to sell some of its Gulf of Mexico assets for around USD 1bln. MecardoLibre (MELI) traded lower after Amazon (AMZN) announced it will launch its prime subscription service in Brazil as it aims to expand in the largest LATAM economy. S&P 500 0% at 2979, NASDAQ-100 -0.2% at 7815, Dow Jones 0.3% at 26909.

Yields jumped across the curve by between 8-9bps at settlement, though major curve spreads were around 1bps narrower. Better risk sentiment -- where talks/between US and China are progressing, with some suggestions of compromises, while geopolitics regarding US/Iran is moving in a friendlier direction after the sacking of WH Adviser Bolton -- as well as hopes of stimulus from the ECB this week (and likely looser policy from the Fed next week, with sources suggesting the BOJ could join the party too) have lessened the need for safer assets. This week's supply and heavy corporate issuance were also said to have weighed on the complex. US T-notes (Z9) settled 22+ ticks lower at 130-05.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 10th September 2019: Trade and geopolitics supportive ahead of Thursday’s ECB
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries lower, Crude lower, Dollar flat
  • REAR VIEW: China ready to purchase US goods, Bolton gone, EIA downgrades global oil demand forecast, ECB & BOJ sources
  • COMING UP:  Data: US PPI & EIA Weekly Report, Event: OPEC Monthly Report, Auction: Australian supply and US 10-year auction

US MARKET WRAP 10th September 2019: Trade and geopolitics supportive ahead of Thursday’s ECB

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries lower, Crude lower, Dollar flat

* REAR VIEW: China ready to purchase US goods, Bolton gone, EIA downgrades global oil demand forecast, ECB & BOJ sources

* COMING UP: Data: US PPI & EIA Weekly Report, Event: OPEC Monthly Report, Auction: Australian supply and US 10-year auction

 

* US/CHINA: With trade teams set to hold talks next week, China Premier Li, speaking on state radio, said that US and China should find a solution to the ongoing trade dispute, and was hopeful that trade talks could make progress. From the US side, White House adviser Navarro called for patience ahead of key US/China talks planned for next month, when top officials from Beijing will visit in Washington. China's SCMP reported that China was ready to sweeten a trade deal by buying US goods, a source said; the piece also stated that any purchase agreement was no certainty, and the purchasing of US goods would be in exchange for a delay on tariffs, easing of restrictions on Huawei; China could offer more market access and better IP protection as well as cutting industrial capacity, but would be reluctant to compromise on subsidies, industrial policies and reform of SOEs. Elsewhere, US Commerce Department's preliminary findings shows that imports of ceramic tiles from China have been subsidies unfairly; have put preliminary duties of 103.77-222.24% on Chinese ceramic tile imports.

* GEOPOLITICS: US President Trump said he sacked security advisor John Bolton, saying he disagreed strongly with some of his suggestions. Bolton was considered a trade/international relations hawk, and as such, analysts think this could open the way for more constructive talks with China, and possibly others. Bolton has also been hawkish on foreign policy, and as such, may pave the way for more constructive talks with the likes of Iran. Israel PM Netanyahu says he intends to annex Jordan Valley in the West Bank, which had been hinted at earlier. It was also a key campaign pledge. Later, the US Treasury has issued sanctions on a series of terrorist leaders, facilitators and entities under new counter-terrorism sanctions authority which includes Hamaas, Islamic State, Al Qaeda and Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.

* EIA STEO: US EIA cuts its 2019 forecast for world oil demand growth by 100K BPD, and now forecasts 900k BPD y/y increase; it cut its 2020 world oil demand growth view by 30k, now seeing 1.4mln BPD y/y increase. In terms of output, 2019 US Crude output is set to rise by 1.25mln BPD to 12.24mln BPD (Prev. month 1.28mln BPD increase), while 2020 US Crude output is seen rising 990k BPD to 13.23mln BPD (Prev. month 13.26mln BPD). NOTE: the IEA is expected to cut its world oil demand forecast by around 100k as well, according to its chief Birrol on Monday. Meanwhile, OPEC's SecGen Barkindo on Tuesday said OPEC's world oil demand forecasts have been conservative, and he saw no recession ahead, suggesting that the cartel might not join the EIA and IEA in cutting their demand view.

* WTI (V9) SETTLES USD 0.45 LOWER AT USD 57.40/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLES USD 0.21 LOWER AT USD 62.38/BBL: The crude complex was higher in early trade on Tuesday, with traders continuing to cite the new Saudi energy minister's commitment to the supply curb pact as a key pillar supporting oil. However, there was negative ticks in the complex on news that US President Trump had sacked adviser John Bolton, considered a hawk. Analysts said that this may potentially open up a more constructive tone on foreign policy and on trade talks. It also suggests that a meeting between the US and Iran at this month's UN conference becomes a more realistic possibility, and may contribute to the geopolitical risk premium being priced out of (or to a lesser extent) within the crude complex.

* ECB SOURCES: Sources reportedly said that the ECB could delay the launch of any QE, and tie it to data when it is launched. The article reportedly said that amid strong disagreement over how much stimulus was needed, policymakers could lean towards tying it to further economic downside. The central bank this week is expected to launch a package of easing measures; RANsquawk's ECB preview can be accessed here.

* BOJ SOURCES: The BoJ's decision on when/whether to ease will be a close call, sources said, as policymakers are growing less confident in global growth. Taking rates further into negative territory is among options, but other measures are not off the table, the report said, adding that no decision has been taken yet, and the decision will be a close call (potentially at the last minute). If rates were moved further into negative territory, the report suggested that there could be accompanying mitigating measures for banks. The piece reiterated that the BoJ's tool box includes deepening negative rates, cutting 10-year JGB target, ramping up purchases of risky assets, as well as printing more money.

* EUROPEAN POLITICS: Italy PM Conte says he wants reform of EU stability pact, and more scope for investment. In Spain, talks between the PSOE and Podemos looked to have stalled, raising the possibility of elections on 10th November if no coalition can be formed by next week. In the UK, EU is reportedly looking to a Northern Ireland-only backstop to break Brexit deadlock (an idea previously rejected by PM May), with EU sources insisting that there was no other workable approach; a senior ERG source says if UK PM Johnson goes for an all-Ireland backstop that 'throws the DUP under the bus' the deal would not get through the Commons. Elsewhere, UK PM Johnson reiterated that there was a way of getting a Brexit deal with the EU. In Europe, incoming EC Chief Von Der Leyen says the UK would need to appoint a commissioner if the Brexit deadline is extended.

* BOE: BoE Governor Carney said the Bank does not see large imbalances in the economy, that would normally precipitate a slowdown, adding that the BoE has the tools to deal with any economic slowdown. The Governor reiterated that the BoE could release countercyclical capital buffers for banks in the event of a downturn, but does not see negative interest rates as a tool in the UK. On markets more broadly, he warned that we are getting closer to a global liquidity trap. Carney also said that the Fed has monetary policy room to deal with a slowdown, BoE is close and ECB is further away.

* US T-NOTES (Z9) SETTLES 22+ TICKS LOWER AT 130-05. Yields jumped across the curve by between 8-9bps at settlement, though major curve spreads were around 1bps narrower. Better risk sentiment -- where talks/between US and China are progressing, with some suggestions of compromises, while geopolitics regarding US/Iran is moving in a friendlier direction after the sacking of WH Adviser Bolton -- as well as hopes of stimulus from the ECB this week (and likely looser policy from the Fed next week, with sources suggesting the BOJ could join the party too) have lessened the need for safer assets. This week's supply and heavy corporate issuance were also said to have weighed on the complex.

* 3-YEAR AUCTION: It was a mixed 3-year note auction, which tailed by 0.3bps, with similar cover to the August auction; cover was a touch softer than recent averages, though was in line with the prior; dealer participation picked-up versus the prior as well as recent averages, while directs were more or less in line with recent performance. Indirect participation was also in line with recent averages. In wake of the auction, the TPLEX continued to see yields rise, with the 10-year yield topping 1.70% again, ahead of Wednesday's auction.

* US 10-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Analysts at SocGen says the 10-year part of the curve does not have clear set up for the upcoming auction from a relative value perspective, arguing that it appears rich on asset swap versus the previous 10-year auction cycle, though it does look cheap on the curve versus 5s and 30s. SocGen says the steepening of 2s10s seen since late August, however, does make the sector look attractive, though the bank highlights that 2s10s has actually flattened by around 10bps since the previous auction cycle (NOTE: August's auction was soft). On the other side of the coin, SocGen observes that the current 10-year note trades special in repo, and dealer holdings in the 7-10 year bucket is low; both of these factors could be supportive for the auction. "Even so," SocGen writes, "the auction will likely demand a concession to go well, as the current WI yield is well below all auction stops since August 2016." The bank says it is neutral on the September 10-year auction.

* FX WRAP: DXY is slightly firmer, though is within Monday's trading range, with desks attributing the limited bouts of upside to risk aversion, as stocks moved lower. JPY traded higher to just shy of 107.50, though heads into APAC trade flat, eyeing the MOF's business conditions survey overnight; sources also raise the possibility of looser measures from the BOJ. XAU remains sub-1500 as Treasury yields tick up, and geopolitics seemingly moves in a friendlier direction. EUR firmed after a sources report suggesting a QE announcement this week is still not a done deal. GBP is flat at around 1.2350, having ventured up to 1.2375; Parliament is now prorogued, and it may allow GBP to take a more quiet path of trade; vols have edged lower, though desks still see election risks presenting downside to GBP, and as such, it remains a sell on rallies, desks say. NOK and SEK are both lower against the EUR following inflation data. CAD went higher with oil in early trade, while housing starts and building permits surprised to the upside; some reports suggest PM Trudeau will call for elections on Wednesday; the Loonie retained gains, despite oil going negative on geopolitics. AUD flat, business conditions and confidence fell, data from NAB showed.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0% at 2979, NASDAQ-100 -0.2% at 7815, Dow Jones 0.3% at 26909.

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.4%, Consumer Staple -0.6%, Energy 1.3%, Financials 0.4%, Health Care 0.3%, Industrials 1%, Information Technology -0.5%, Materials 1%, Telecommunication Services 0%, Utilities 0.1%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple’s (AAPL) new event saw the announcement of a streaming service priced at USD 4.99/mth which weighed on Netflix (NFLX), Disney (DIS) and Roku (ROKU), and a new health app put pressure on Fitbit (FIT). iPhone entry level prices were slightly cheaper than its XR equivalents, with the iPhone 11 to start from USD 699, and the PRO model at USD 999, and the PRO MAX at USD 1099; a new iWatch and iPad were also announced. Ford (F) was hit after is unsecured debt was downgraded to junk at Moody's, however, desks had mixed views, with BofAML suggesting it may be a sign of more to come, whereas Credit Suisse believes it did little to affect Ford’s ongoing business. Boeing’s (BA) gross orders for August stood at 185, however, net orders were -15 due to cancellations, also likely impacted by different airlines pushing back their expected return of the 737 MAX. JPMorgan’s (JPM) CEO Dimon expects Q3 trading revenues to rise 10% Y/Y in Q3, but caveated it with ‘Q318 was not great’. Wendy’s (WEN) announced it is to initiate a breakfast menu at 300 restaurants next year and will hire 20,000 new employees to support the move. The fast food restaurant then cut the top end of its FY19 Adj. EPS growth view to 3.5-6.5% from 3.5-7%. In M&A, Renault (RNO FP) CEO stated it is no longer in discussion with Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) and that the main priority is having Nissan (NSANY) back on schedule. Exxon (XOM) was higher after sources said it was in advanced talks with Repsol (REP SM) to sell some of its Gulf of Mexico assets for around USD 1bln. MecardoLibre (MELI) traded lower after Amazon (AMZN) announced it will launch its prime subscription service in Brazil as it aims to expand in the largest LATAM economy.

subject: WATCH LIVE: Apple Annual Launch Event
content: Click here for link
analysis_details:
• Tech giant Apple (AAPL) is expected to launch new iPhones at its event on Tuesday, including iPhone 11 (5.8 inch OLED), 11 Pro (6.5 inch OLED) and 11R (6.1 inch LCD).
  • The phones will likely see processors upgraded, while the OLED versions are expected to feature a triple lens camera (the LCD version will have a two-lens); wireless charging is also expected to feature, while 3D Touch may be replaced by haptic feedback.
  • "While some investors may consider the set of new features to be lacklustre, we point out that our research on Apple's iPhone installed base and on-going global survey suggests that there could be 200mln really old iPhones still in use (iPhone 6, or earlier)," BofAML said, "these old phones would be candidates for upgrade and we continue to look at FY2020 as a 'Trade-in' iPhone cycle vs. FY2021, which should be a '5G driven cycle'."
  • BofAML continues to model 185mln, 190mlnm and 220mln iPhone sales in FY 2019, 2020 and 2021 respectively.
  • The key factor to watch, Bank of America says, is how Apple prices the new iPhones - that will determine the success. "Apple saw meaningful elasticity of demand in China when it lowered the price of iPhone XR, and we expect Apple to potentially lower pricing of some models. New US tariffs on China-made cell phones and laptops were delayed to 15th December and we expect Apple to not raise prices related to tariffs, just yet."
  • Elsewhere, the bank will be on the lookout for a new Apple watch, which may have sleep-monitoring sensors, and also new titanium casings.
  • There is also a possibility of a new 16-inch MacBook Pro launch, and also keep an ear out for details on new Apple services, like Apple TV+, and Apple Arcade.
  • "Apple stock has typically traded up into such launch events, pulled back slightly after the event, and then recovered 60 days post the event," the bank observes; BofAML reiterated its 'buy' rating on Apple this week, on growing iOS installed base, and new Services and products to come.

Daily FX Wrap: risk tone turns twitchy and more temperate on Tuesday
content:
G10

Little deviation in Usd/major pairings, but some currencies have pared worst losses and others swapped positions. Of note, the Swedish Krona has rebounded from 10.7740+ peaks against the single currency as Riksbank Governor Ingves played down softer than expected inflation again and contended that prospects of a major slowdown in growth are low. In short, guidance for a further 25 bp hike late this year or in early 2020 remain intact and Eur/SEK has retreated towards 10.7150 alongside Eur/NOK from 9.9200 or so to sub-9.8900, with the Norwegian Crown also regrouping after weaker than forecast headline and core CPI data.

CHF/GBP/CAD 

All moderately firmer vs the Greenback that remains rangebound overall (DXY still hovering just below 98.500 within a relatively narrow 98.465-260 band), with the Franc eying resistance/offers at 0.9900 and Cable back up over 1.2350, but again unable to reach stops residing at 1.2385+, while Eur/Gbp pulled up before 0.8900 and not far from chart support breached though not convincingly broken earlier. Elsewhere, the Loonie got boost from better than expected Canadian housing data and firmer oil prices to revisit 1.3150 vs circa 1.3190 at the other extreme.

AUD/JPY/EUR/NZD

A bit more downside for the Aussie, but Aud/Usd held comfortably above the 0.6850 level as Usd/Cnh continues to consolidate off recent highs after another incremental dip in the PBoC’s official Usd/Cny midpoint fixing overnight, while the Aud/Nzd cross also crept back up towards 1.0700 as the Kiwi slipped a tad closer to 0.6400. The Yen and Euro both remained contained between 107.19-49 and 1.1059-31 in the face of somewhat contrasting BoJ and ECB sourced reports suggesting new stimulus from the former will likely be a tight call and ultimately decided at the last minute, while the latter may not decide to deliver QE this Thursday, but stagger an easing package to see how data unfolds.

EM

No respite for the Try as aggressive CBRT rate cut calls grow louder (500 bp among the latest in the Turkish press) and sanction jitters weigh on sentiment ahead of a joint media briefing from top US officials at 18.30BST. The Lira hit lows of around 5.7870, while the Rand and Rouble forged more gains vs the Buck in contrast circa 14.6550 and over 65.4000 at one stage, Rub deriving traction from the aforementioned rise in Brent and Zar not unduly perturbed by latest fiscal warnings from Moody’s.

subject: Market Update: Futures fall at cash open, Energy and Financials outperforming
analysis_details: • US Equity Futures fell at the open, catching up with the cash markets, with SPX approx -0.5% lower at the time of writing. The energy sector leads the way as the crude complex remains in the green, meanwhile Financials are currently in second place, buoyed by higher yields. Tech and consumer discretionary sectors are the laggards, at -1.4% and -1.0% lower respectively at the time of writing, and are accompanied by the typically defensive health care, consumer staples sectors who are also being hit. Utilities quickly reversed opening losses and the sector is currently flat.

  • Merck & Co. (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced that pooled analysis of its Keytruda continues to show that when used with chemotherapy the overall survival rate was improved when compared with chemotherapy alone for patients with advanced NSCLC whose tumours do not express PD-L1.

Elsewhere, a US Treasury Official stated that Libra’s only chance of succeeding is by ensuring highest Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Finance Terrorism standards. Also the social media giant will have to face most of a class action suit seeking damages for alleged privacy violations after a ruling from a federal judge. (CNBC)

Elsewhere, a driver was caught sleeping whilst driving according to WHDH TV news, however CEO Elon Musk retweeted a piece this morning which stated that Tesla’s do not allow drivers to fall asleep at the wheel. Also of note, Continental (CON GY) CEO says they would be willing to co-operate with Daimler (DAI GY) on autonomous driving. (Twitter/Newswires)

S&P 500

  • Bristol Myers Squibb (BMY) (Healthcare/Pharmaceuticals) 5-year OPDIVO results show that patients treated with OPDIVO did continue to experience long term overall survival benefit when compared to Docetaxel. OS rate for OPDIVO at 5 years were 13.4% and 2.6% for Docetaxel and benefits were observed across all subgroups.
  • Coty, Inc (COTY) (Consumer Staples/Personal Products) executive has purchased 210k class a shares valued at USD 1.85mln.

However, Credit Suisse says it does little to affect Ford’s ongoing business but Bank of America state it may be a sign of more things to come with potentially other downgrades. Elsewhere, the US House Judiciary Committee reportedly is to examine the automaker antitrust investigation. Also Ford has revealed an EV line up, with 17 cars in Europe by 2024, including 8 in 2019, which will surpass petrol and diesel by 2022 and it expects that over half of its passenger vehicle sales by the end of 2022 will be driven by electrified powertrains. F also expect to have sold 1mln electrified passenger vehicles by 2022.

Sanderson Asset Management are to vote against the proposed takeover of Cobham (COB LN) by Advent International, according to the FT

Riksbank Governor Ingves does not see a major downturn around the corner, expects growth rate to come down slightly in coming years; adds that inflation expectations have dipped lately but nothing we are too concerned over
analysis_details:
• Follows on from this morning saw the CPIF metrics for August which missed expectations by 0.2ppts for the YY metrics coming in at 1.3%; which may be interpreted as Governor Ingves pushing backing somewhat on the broader implications of the data missing.
  • Although, these comments by Ingves are broadly in-line with the comments from the most recent Bank meeting where they noted that some risks have emerged but they do intend to hike at the end of this year or the start of next year.

subject: BoE Governor Carney says the BoE does not see large imbalances in economic that would normally precipitate a slowdown, BoE has the tools to deal with an economic slowdown
content:
• Governor reiterates that BoE could release countercyclical capital buffers for banks in the event of a downturn
  • Carney says we are getting closer to a global liquidity trap
  • Fed has monetary policy room to deal with a slowdown, BoE is close and ECB is further away

subject: White House Trade Advisor Navarro says USMCA deal should transcend politics, is a great deal for the US and "has" to get done this year; says we need to be patient regarding US/China trade talks
content:
• assigns a 100% probability to USMCA being passed this year
  • says if Germany engaged in fiscal stimulus, Dow could see 500 point gain in one day
  • when asked about any potential delay to tariffs, says he does not wish to speculate and went back to "Lighthizer rule" - where he says "if USTR Lighthizer hasn't said it, it is likely to be fake news"

subject: BoJ decision on when/whether to ease will be a close call, policymakers are growing less confident in global growth, taking rates further into negative territory is among options but other options are not off of the table., according to sources
content:
• Decision on whether to ease will be a close call, conclusion may not come until last minute
  • If rates go deeper into negative territory, BoJ may need to accompany that with mitigating measures
  • Deepening negative rates, cutting 10yr JGB target, ramping up purchases of risky assets and printing money are among choices
analysis_details: • Next BoJ meeting will take place on 19th September

subject: Incoming EC Chief Von Der Leyen says the UK would need to appoint a commissioner if the Brexit deadline is extended
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are slightly softer but overall little changed as markets await a substantial catalyst ahead of Thursday’s ECB
  • US President Trump reiterated that China wants to talk, and it was also reported that China is hopeful US can create conditions for trade talks
  • USD remains little changed vs. G10 counterparts though SEK & NOK remain subdued on domestic factors
  • Looking ahead, highlights EIA STEO, APIs, BoE’s Carney & Riksbank’s Ingves, US 3yr supply

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as they followed suit to the indecisive tone seen on Wall St amid a sell-off in treasuries and as the region also digested ambiguous inflation figures from China. ASX 200 (-0.5%) was negative with gold miners frontrunning the declines in Australia after the precious metal slipped below the psychological key USD 1500/oz level but with further losses in the index stemmed by strength in the energy sector following the recent rally in oil prices, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was kept afloat by favourable currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) gave back initial gains despite the liquidity efforts by the PBoC and firmer than expected Chinese inflation data, as the figures were largely influenced by a 10% increase in food prices amid the swine fever epidemic and also showed PPI at its sharpest contraction in 3 years. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower following the bear-steepening seen in US and broad declines across global bonds, while the absence of the BoJ from the market today also added to the lacklustre demand.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0846 vs. Exp. 7.0958 (Prev. 7.0851) 

Chinese CPI (Aug) Y/Y 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.8%), food prices rose 10% Y/Y, pork prices rose 47% Y/Y. (Newswires) Chinese PPI (Aug) Y/Y -0.8% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. -0.3%); steepest decline since August 2016.

US President Trump reiterated that China wants to talk, and it was also reported that China is hopeful US can create conditions for trade talks. (Newswires/China Daily)

Huawei abandoned its lawsuit against the US government regarding seizure of its telecoms equipment, while there were separate report the Co. expects to be able to release first Google-free smartphone by Spring next year, and that the US filed criminal charges against a Chinese professor in Texas who is linked to Huawei. (Newswires/WSJ)

China is very restrained on the trade war and other issues., Chinese Global Times Editor. (Twitter)

China FX regulator has decided to remove QFII and RQFII quotas, will remove requirement on countries and regions on RQFII scheme. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea launched 2 projectiles, although a Japanese Defence Ministry official later commented that the latest North Korea missiles pose no immediate threat to Japan's national security. (Newswires/Yonhap)

Pakistani Foreign Minister has told UN Human Rights council that India's "illegal Kashmir military occupation" raises spectre of "genocide". Additionally, Pakistan's Qureshi says that he sees 'no possibility of a bilateral engagement with India'. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Parliament also rejected holding an early election as 293 voted for it vs. 46 against, which is short of the 434 votes or two-thirds majority needed for a snap election. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said the government will press on with negotiating a Brexit deal and that he will go to the EU Summit on October 17th to strive to get an agreement, while he also reiterated the government will not delay Brexit. Elsewhere, Tory MPs confirmed they were told PM Johnson is opening the door for a return of rebels but will require a show of loyalty. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn said they will not vote for an election until no-deal is off the table. In other news, Labour is reportedly considering tabling a confidence vote on PM Johnson on October 22nd after instructing its MPs to vote down the Queen's Speech a day beforehand. (Newswires/Telegraph)

German Finance Minister Scholz says Germany will have billions to use if there is an economic crisis due to strong foundations it has built for growth. (Newswires)

UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M YY Jul 4.0% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.7%, Rev. 3.8%)

- UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) Jul 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.9%)

- UK ILO Unemployment Rate Jul 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.9% (Prev. 3.9%)

EQUITIES

European equities are modestly softer [Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%] following on from a mixed Asia-Pac session as participants remain on standby ahead of Thursday’s ECB monetary policy decision. Sectors are mixed with underperformance in the IT sector, whilst energy names outperform as the oil complex holds onto its recent gains and banking names remain supported by yesterday’s surge in yields (RBS +4.4%, UBS +3.4%, Barclays +4.5%). In terms of stocks on the move, EDF (-7.5%) share fell from the open after the Co. noted deviations in technical standards governing the manufacture of nuclear-reactor components. On the flip side, Subsea 7 (+2.7%) shares opened higher after the Co. announced its current COO as the new CEO effective January 1st 2020, additionally the Co. were awarded an offshore contract in Saudi Arabia. Finally, JD Sports (+3%) shares are supported post earnings after H1 sales rose 47% Y/Y and the Co. forecasts FY results to be at the mid-point of their previously guided range.

TSMC (2330 TT) - August sales TWD 106.12bln vs. Prev. TWD 91.1bln. (Newswires)

FX

SEK/NOK - The major underperformers in wake of softer than forecast Swedish and Norwegian inflation data that calls into question hawkish guidance from the Riksbank and Norges Bank. Eur/Sek has rebounded from sub-10.7000 levels through 10.7500 and breached several technical resistance points in the process, including 10 and 21 DMAs plus a Fib retracement, while Eur/Nok is back above 9.9000 from almost 9.8500 and also taking on board the latest Norges Bank regional network survey showing that contacts envisage slightly slower growth in the coming 6 months.

USD - The Dollar is mixed to marginally firmer awaiting this week’s top-tier US data for more input ahead of the September FOMC after last Friday’s rather inconclusive BLS report and broadly upbeat comments from Fed chair Powell, on balance. However, the DXY remains rangebound between 98.260-463 and well within near term chart support and resistance not to mention recent highs and lows for the index.

CHF/NZD/AUD - The Franc has pared some losses vs the Greenback and single currency as risk appetite wanes/falters and selling abates into key technical psychological markers, like 0.9950 in Usd/Chf and 1.1000 in Eur/Chf. Meanwhile, the Aussie and Kiwi have lost some momentum, with Aud/Usd drifting back towards 0.6850 in wake of a downturn in NAB business sentiment and dip in conditions overnight, and Nzd/Usd fading ahead of 0.6450 as Aud/Nzd meanders between 1.0645-85.

GBP/CAD/JPY/EUR - Sterling staged another attempt to hunt out stops around 1.2385 vs the Buck and briefly crossed the 100 DMA against the Euro (0.8930), but failed to sustain momentum again amidst the ongoing UK political and Brexit paralysis. However, the ensuing Pound pull-back was arrested by more encouraging data as earnings beat consensus on a headline basis and the jobless rate eased to 3.8% from 3.9%. Note also, 2 bn option expiries in Cable at the 1.2300 strike have provided a buffer. Elsewhere, trade has been considerably more rangebound with the Loonie straddling 1.3175, Yen holding within 107.19-49 parameters and Euro stuck in a 1.1037-59 band awaiting Thursday’s ECB policy pronouncements for more direction.

EM - Contrasting fortunes again for the Rand and Lira, as Usd/Zar continues its deep reversal from 15.0000+ towards 14.6900 regardless of more SA ratings warnings from Moody’s, but Usd/Try elevated above 5.7500 in the run up to this week’s CBRT rate verdict and heeding even more dovish calls (-500 bp touted in a Turkish paper) alongside the persistent threat of US sanctions.

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Aug) 1 (Prev. 4). (Newswires)

Australian NAB Business Conditions (Aug) 1 (Prev. 2)

Norwegian Consumer Price Index YY Aug 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.9%)

- Norwegian Consumer Price Index MM Aug -0.7% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Prev. 0.7%)

Swedish CPIF YY Aug 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%)

- Swedish CPIF MM Aug -0.4% (Prev. 0.4%)

FIXED

Yet more see-saw price action and again Gilts have been in the thick of it, with a reversal from Liffe peaks in wake, albeit somewhat belatedly, of more above consensus UK data. However, amidst stellar demand for long-dated DMO supply and another emphatic rebound in Bunds that has spilled over to US Treasuries where futures have pared losses and quite severe curve steepening has been unwound, 10 year benchmarks have regrouped ahead of the US open. The question is now, is the latest move sustainable or just transitory before another retreat.

Moody's has reduced its 2019 forecast for Italian growth to 0.2% from 0.4%, see Italy's growth accelerating to 0.5% next year. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are holding onto most of its recent gains with the two benchmarks around 58.00/bbl and 63/bbl respectively at the time of writing. News-flow for the complex has been light, although reports stated that Russia’s Energy Minister Novak will be meeting with newly appointed Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz in Jeddah later today to discuss the energy market alongside strengthening Saudi-Russia cooperation ahead of Thursday’s JMMC meeting. Meanwhile, Nigeria’s Finance Ministry notes of strong indications of an oil glut next year, and thus lowered its benchmark forecast to 55/bbl from 60/bbl. This evening will also see the release of EIA’s Short-Term Energy Outlook with focus on global demand growth forecasts. Looking further ahead, participants will also be eyeing the weekly API crude inventory data with markets expecting a headline drawdown of 2.5mln barrels. Elsewhere, gold prices are largely unchanged below the 1500/oz mark amid the undecisive risk tone in the market ahead of this week’s key events. Meanwhile, copper prices have seen a more pronounced downside compared to yesterday with the red-metal flirting with 2.60/lb to the downside at the time of writing. Finally, Dalian iron ore prices advanced as much as 4% amid expectations that China will ratify further economic stimulus that would boost steel demand.

Iraq Oil Minister sees new projects to provide additional 2mln bpd capacity in next few years. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs continue to see Brent oil price of USD 60/bbl next year amid OPEC willingness to sacrifice market share; GS lower their 2019 oil demand growth expectation to 10mln bpd from 11mln bpd. (Newswires)

Nigeria's Oil Minister says Nigeria's oil production exceeds OPEC's target but not everyday, will comply with OPEC. (Newswires)

Nigeria oil production to average 2.3mln BPD in 2019 (August production at 1.93mln BPD), 2020 projected at 2.18mln BPD, Finance Minister states, notes of strong indications of an oil glut in 2020, lowers price forecast to USD 55/bbl (Prev. 60/bbl)

Nomura says performance of high-beta factor in US stocks driven by Chinese economic momentum
content:
• Nomura observes that the recent risk rally has been powered by exits from pessimistic trades, driven primarily by optimism over Chinese policy authorities' recently announced economic stimulus measures and improved perceived prospects for the outcome of upcoming US-China trade negotiations. The rally thus far, they argue, has been mostly a matter of investors downsizing the risk-off positions they had built up in August and, judging from our estimates of how long it will take investors to exit these positions, the bank thinks “a moment of reckoning” for the sustainability of the rally may occur sometime between 17 and 23 September. Global macro hedge funds, Nomura says, have over the last two trading days swung to taking profits on their US equity longs and US bond shorts.
  • Nomura highlight a noteworthy change in factor trends yesterday; trend-chasing CTAs have already swung to rebuilding their long position in US equity futures. This, the bank argues, is showing up precisely where one would expect; in a return to purchases of high-beta stocks and cyclicals. Moreover, the pattern of trading in US equities by long/short funds also indicates that these funds have pared long positions in defensive sectors while adding to long positions in cyclical sectors.
  • So how far might this rebound in high-beta stocks and cycles go? Nomura notes that the performance of the high-beta factor in the US stock market (high-beta longs and low-beta shorts) tends to be consistent with Chinese economic momentum, about which concerns have eased somewhat since the recently announced measures to be undertaken by Chinese policy authorities. However, until it becomes clear that China's economy is on a recovery path, the outperformance of the high-beta factor will probably be primarily a matter of exits from high-beta factor short positions that investors staked out with a bit too much haste, the bank suggests.
  • Nomura also note the recent move higher in UST yields, which are now above 1.64% for the 10-year; investors are increasingly backing out of long positions in US bonds taken out in August in the context of a flight to quality, observes the bank, adding that momentum-chasing algos (CTAs, risk-parity funds) are being pulled along by this trend. These systematic players seem to be loss cutting by liquidating long positions in UST futures, triggered by the recent break in 10yr UST yields above 1.56%, which is the bank’s estimate of the cost of CTAs ' net buying of TY since the beginning of August.

content: Eurozone bonds are attempting to stabilise after yesterday’s sharp sell-off that was exacerbated by more reports about German fiscal stimulus via supplementary budget that would not contravene or impinge on strict debt targets. As such, the core debt future has regained some composure and trades back in positive territory just shy of fresh Eurex highs having opened at 174.31 vs Monday’s 174.24 close and retreating to 174.18 at one stage. However, bulls/buyers face technical resistance around the current 174.43 peak head of 174.50 and then the 174.59-62 area that represented trend-line support on the way down. In terms of what lies ahead, Italian IP and not a lot more as the clock ticks down to this week’s major event on Thursday when the ECB reveals the extent of its widely anticipated easing package.

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as they followed suit to the indecisive tone seen on Wall St amid a sell-off in treasuries and as the region also digested ambiguous inflation figures from China. ASX 200 (-0.7%) was negative with gold miners frontrunning the declines in Australia after the precious metal slipped below the psychological key USD 1500/oz level but with further losses in the index stemmed by strength in the energy sector following the recent rally in oil prices, while Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was kept afloat by favourable currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. Co. state this will likely cost them around GBP 40mln per day of strike action. Delay's are also expected on Wednesday due to the backlog in cancellations. BALPA union noted that there are no further talks planned with BA at the moment. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 10th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed, following suit from the indecisive tone seen on Wall St
  • Chinese inflation metrics were largely influenced by a 10% increase in food prices amid the swine fever epidemic, PPI saw its sharpest contraction in 3 years
  • US President Trump reiterated that China wants to talk whilst it was also reported that China is hopeful US can create the conditions for trade talks
  • MPs scuppered PM Johnson’s attempt for a snap election just before Parliament began its 5-week suspension
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Employment Data, EIA STEO, APIs, BoE’s Carney & Riksbank’s Ingves, US 3yr supply

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as they followed suit to the indecisive tone seen on Wall St amid a sell-off in treasuries and as the region also digested ambiguous inflation figures from China. ASX 200 (-0.7%) was negative with gold miners frontrunning the declines in Australia after the precious metal slipped below the psychological key USD 1500/oz level but with further losses in the index stemmed by strength in the energy sector following the recent rally in oil prices, while Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was kept afloat by favourable currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) gave back initial gains despite the liquidity efforts by the PBoC and firmer than expected Chinese inflation data, as the figures were largely influenced by a 10% increase in food prices amid the swine fever epidemic and also showed PPI at its sharpest contraction in 3 years. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower following the bear-steepening seen in US and broad declines across global bonds, while the absence of the BoJ from the market today also added to the lacklustre demand.

 

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0846 vs. Exp. 7.0958 (Prev. 7.0851) 

Chinese CPI (Aug) Y/Y 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.8%), food prices rose 10% Y/Y, pork prices rose 47% Y/Y. (Newswires) Chinese PPI (Aug) Y/Y -0.8% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. -0.3%); steepest decline since August 2016.

 

US President Trump reiterated that China wants to talk, and it was also reported that China is hopeful US can create conditions for trade talks. (Newswires/China Daily)

 

Huawei abandoned its lawsuit against the US government regarding seizure of its telecoms equipment, while there were separate report the Co. expects to be able to release first Google-free smartphone by Spring next year, and that the US filed criminal charges against a Chinese professor in Texas who is linked to Huawei. (Newswires/WSJ)

 

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he is looking forward to completing a deal with Japan at the UN General Assembly and stated they have reached a consensus on agricultural, digital and industrial issues. (Twitter)

UK/EU

UK parliament voted (311-302) in favour of forcing the government to show all documents regarding its no-deal planning as well as private messages related to the decision to suspend parliament as expected. Parliament also rejected holding an early election as 293 voted for it vs. 46 against, which is short of the 434 votes or two-thirds majority needed for a snap election. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said the government will press on with negotiating a Brexit deal and that he will go to the EU Summit on October 17th to strive to get an agreement, while he also reiterated the government will not delay Brexit. Elsewhere, Tory MPs confirmed they were told PM Johnson is opening the door for a return of rebels but will require a show of loyalty. (Newswires/Twitter)

 

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn said they will not vote for an election until no-deal is off the table. In other news, Labour is reportedly considering tabling a confidence vote on PM Johnson on October 22nd after instructing its MPs to vote down the Queen's Speech a day beforehand. (Newswires/Telegraph) 

Germany could reportedly face a shortfall in tax revenue in 2020/21. (Handelsblatt)

 

FX

 

DXY was slightly firmer amid a rebound from yesterday’s lows and as EUR/USD continued to retrace the advances that were spurred by news of Germany considering the creation of a 'shadow budget', with expectations of a looming ECB stimulus package this week the main restraint on the single currency. GBP/USD traded relatively steady at the 1.2300 handle after the latest slew of events in which the no-deal Brexit extension bill was given Royal Assent, while lawmakers also approved the motion to force the government to show all documents regarding its no-deal planning and scuppered PM Johnson’s attempt for a snap election just before Parliament began its 5-week suspension. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses held on to recent gains and antipodeans were mixed in which AUD/USD reversed the initial support from a stronger PBoC reference rate, due to weaker NAB Business Confidence figures and somewhat misleading Chinese inflation numbers.

 

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Aug) 1 (Prev. 4). (Newswires)

Australian NAB Business Conditions (Aug) 1 (Prev. 2)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures marginally extended on the prior day’s rally to above the USD 58.00/bbl with the recent upside attributed to the change of guard at OPEC’s top producer. Furthermore, Saudi has vowed it would continue to support output cuts under new energy minister Prince Abdulaziz and some have suggested the change has raised anticipation  heading into the JMMC in Abu Dhabi this week for any changes to the kingdom’s policy or its signals regarding the oil market and compliance by other producers. Elsewhere, gold languished after its slip below USD 1500/oz and amid mild strength in the greenback, while copper was resilient as it rebounded overnight with prices unfazed by the indecisive risk tone.

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump said he could meet with Iran's Rouhani and has no problem with the idea, while he stated 'we'll see what happens' regarding a meeting with North Korea in September. (Newswires)

 

North Korea launched 2 projectiles, although a Japanese Defence Ministry official later commented that the latest North Korea missiles pose no immediate threat to Japan's national security. (Newswires/Yonhap)

 

US

The Treasury curve bear-steepened, taking its cues from the Bund in afternoon trade. Some desks had cited a more constructive risk tone in early trade for the rise in yields, with fewer concerns on the US/China trade front, while the notion of central bank easing was also being attributed (which is difficult to buy, given one usually expects yields to fall on the latter). The US Treasury will this week auction a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wednesday), and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Thursday); UBS notes that that there will be around USD 26bln of cashflows (ex-SOMA) this week, including USD 24bln of redemptions and USD 2bln of coupons. Analysts at BMO say that this week's supply could offer a further concessionary impulse as September's 3s/10s/30s auctions are the final primary market coupon opportunity before the Fed once again (very likely) lowers policy. US T-note (U9) settled 16+ ticks lower at 130-27+.

US Senate Republican leader McConnell says he is expecting a stop-gap government funding bill this month. (Newswires)

Sources close to the White House pointed to the APEC Summit in Chile on November 13th-14th as a possible venue for a follow-up Trump-Xi bilateral meeting, although it was also suggested US and Chinese officials would have to complete two productive rounds of talks before then. (CNBC)
